Abandoned

this commit is no longer needed
Please point to a design for this work.

Hi Patrick 

I am proposing these D-bus interfaces as per redfish schemas
http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/AccountService.v1_15_0.yaml
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/AccountService.yaml
http://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ManagerAccount.v1_12_1.yaml
And where is the internal software design?  Having pointers to Redfish schemas is a good start but that isn't a design.
Ok sure, I will work on design document, may need couple of days to get design document ready.
here is design doc https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/73054

Can this property go to Attributes.interface.yaml as this is a User's property? Why a new interface is needed?
Set default value as 'All'

I was thinking to have separate interface since this MFABypass property will be useful only if MFA feature is enabled in the build, while allows us to have MFA code with meson flag.

I think default value should be "None", Will add new enum "None"

> while allows us to have MFA code with meson flag.

OK. But is it possible to add the complete feature implementation with the compiler flag ON ?

> I think default value should be "None", Will add new enum "None"

The value 'None' will mandate all the multi factor authentications on the user. By default all users should be disabled for multi auth. User can then bypass specific ones as per need.

having this new separate interface will provide flexibility to the implementation.
otherwise I am ok to added this property to Attributes.interface as well.

Suppose if MFAbypass property's default values is set "All" then even though 2 factor Google-authenticator enabled then MFA bypassed for user by default.
unless user explicitly change mfa bypass settings and what's the value user needs to set to avoid bypassing google-authenticator (any other specific) MFA?

Ya makes sense. 
When MFABypass == None implies that - when MFA is enabled at system level - all users are mandated to use MFA unless it's bypassed for any of these types in the enums.
Should this 'None' be added to the DMTF schema as well ?

as per redfish schema "MFABypass" can accept enum values or value can be null.
so when this Dbus enum "None" will be mapped to null value.
Looks good to me. But this can wait until the design document is up for review as per Patricks comment.

In redfish, I can see it is an array.

So, regarding this property under each user, should it also be an array of enums specifying the methods that the user is bypassing?

as per schema its not array 
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/ManagerAccount.v1_12_1.json
can you please paste me where do you see type as array?
got it, MFABypass property must be array of enum values.
`set`
ok, curious to know reasons to use set than array.
You only want a single instance of each enum value, so it is a set.  You don't want `[OneTimePasscode, OneTimePasscode]` to be a valid value here.
Please don't add new InternalFailure responses.  What is a caller suppose to do about this?  If your application is in a bad state, coredump.

ok, but currently bmcweb handles internal errors by return error to redfish clients
if app is coredump then how does bmcweb needs to handle this case?
Why add "All" when we have this as a set?
redfish has "All" to bypass all MFA factors at once.

So Redfish can pass all values in, right?

Having an "All" enumeration leads to confusion in two ways:

1. `[All, SecureID]` -- what does this mean?
2. The server code has more complexity of `if (All or X)` for various branches.
Ug.... another case of Redfish doing crazy stuff.  Lets do what Patrick asked for (because that API makes more sense), and we'll plaster over it in the Redfish code for the All case.
Actually, we're not required to support all of these, right?  Could we just have Bypass: {true, false} and map that to redfish All/None?

I agree that in this example [All, SecureID], 'All' already meant to bypass all authentication factors including SecureID, which does not make sense.
will remove "All" enum values in D-bus.

I think we need to have other enum values to support all other factors of authentication for future enhancements..
(It is hard to get reviewers attention when there are still unresolved comments.  Please mark your comments as "resolved" if you have resolved them.  Just click the "done" button.)
Done
Can we add some more description that this is expected to be implemented on user interfaces only?
Done
This description needs improved.  It's literally just the name of the enum + " enumeration".  It does not describe what it's used for.
Done

Hi Patrick/Ed Tanous

I have addressed your comments on these D-bus commits, can you please review
Can this be renamed as 'MultiFactorAuthType' and be reused in the MultiFactorAuthConfiguration.interface.yaml ?

yeah it makes sense to use common enumerations.

Patrick 
can you please share your views here
is it recommended to use common enumeration across multiple D-bus interfaces?
Yes, please use a common enum.  Pretty sure I've mentioned that elsewhere in this chain of reviews.
does this common enum needs to be defined in separate metadata file?
Would prefer that your next commit is "first" and defines the enum.  That seems to be the most intuitive place for it.
Done
In what cases will we return this now?  You should be failing to parse the dbus message in the binding level and not even get to your daemon code if someone gives a wrong enum value.
ok, in that case does it return valid D-bus error?
Ack, will remove InvalidArgument
Done
nit: `BypassedProtocols` ?
I was just following redfish terminology so that we don't need to translate redfish to D-bus names.
That is not the philosophy of phosphor-dbus-interfaces.
yeah understand,

Couldn't this just be a simple enum now?

MFAIgnored
MFAEnforced

Would be the enumerations
I think its good to re-use the same enumeration which is also satisfies redfish enumerations

My issue with this interface is you're now duplicating information.

What happens if the system mode is changed from msft authentication to google?  Do all users that had msft authentication bypass automatically get added a google authenticator bypass?

What if we add a new protocol type?  Do users get ported forward and bypass the new type?

There are a lot of questions that need answered when doing it this way (that aren't currently answered in the interface description).

Having a simple "auth is bypassed" or "auth isn't bypassed" mode meets the same requirements for redfish.  I'd also note that if this MUST match Redfish

MFAIgnored would be equivalent to the Redfish "All" setting.
MFAEnforced would be equivalent to whatever modes are enabled.


I understand that Redfish made this more complex, because they probably have to support lots of auth mechanisms in parallel.  In openbmc, we don't have to support them in parallel, or if we do, lets treat that as a separate track of work.

I am not sure if the implementation is that simple of we map Every thing to MFAIgnored and MFAEnforced. Each MF option may have different implementation for by pass. It may be just deleting the .google_authenticator file for google case and  different for Microsoft etc. It all depends on what does each pam module expects for MFA. The problem is not just with parallel support. Even if we don't have multiple MFA active in parallel, there is a possibility of each organisation enable different kind of MFA. Implementation of pam module athentication and bypass may differ drastically. So in my opinion it is better to follow redfish schema and implementation can report error back to the client if it choses unsupported MFA options.

Everything you're describing is an internal detail to the service that implements this.  My point is that as much as we can, we should avoid allowing internal details into the dbus API.

FWIW, if you really want to cover the whole range of behavior in the description about how each of those works, feel free to update this patchset, but it doesn't seem worth it to me.  Just support one OTP at a time, make the bypass use its own enum that's bypass/not bypass, and make the rest of the behavior handled in the interface.

What I was saying is that "just follow the interface". Redfish has very generic interface to support various MFA. What you are suggesting is to map the generic interface to a constrained internal interface, just because we don't have support for all of those types now. We can still achieve the same with out any interface mapping code between redfish and DBUS. We can just choose to support enums (None and GoogleAuthenticator). If redfish client send us other values DBus's default implementation will throw unsupported value error. Which is better than doing all those check in Bmcweb's conversion code that maps BypasType to  MFAIgnored and MFAEnforced.

Other question, why is this interface separate from https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/72987/20/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/User/MultiFactorAuthConfiguration.interface.yaml

Aren't they both required to be implemented for a user?  Can we just combine them?

this MFA Bypass interface  will be implemented on user's object since each user can have option to skip mfa.

MultiFactorAuthConfiguration interface will be implemented on User manager D-bus which will be used to enable MFA.

> this MFA Bypass interface  will be implemented on user's object since each user can have option to skip mfa.

Sorry, I linked the wrong interface:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/72602/32/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/User/TOTPAuthenticator.interface.yaml

Is also at user level.  Should they be combined?

> 
> MultiFactorAuthConfiguration interface will be implemented on User manager D-bus which will be used to enable MFA.

I think its better have this Bypass interface separately than combined with TOTP authenticator interface, so that it can easily extended for other multi-factor authentications, Becoz bypass configuration applies to other multi factor methods as well and TOTP authenticator interface has properties specific to only TOTP implementation.

> I think its better have this Bypass interface separately than combined with TOTP authenticator interface, so that it can easily extended for other multi-factor authentications,

And this is my point, as written, it can't be extended, because they all exist on the root user path.  If we're going to do that, make it simple.

> Becoz bypass configuration applies to other multi factor methods as well and TOTP authenticator interface has properties specific to only TOTP implementation.

I can't imagine that supporting this as a multi-map of per-user interfaces is a good idea from a complexity standpoint.  Once we get those requirements, we can discuss.  For now, lets keep this as simple as it can be for the interfaces proposed.
Updated TOTP authenticator interface to have this bypass property
since it is single enum, can we call it BypassedProtocol? For the readability can we call it ActiveMFA?
Just ignore the ActiveMFA name. Just realised that it is not semantically correct. My suggestion is to change BypassedProtocols -> BypassedProtocol
